q2.description: Why do we care? Because we want to parse efficiently. This means, we want to quickly determine if a given string can be generated from a given grammar. Determinism seems to be a fundamental requirement if we hope to do this.
q2.question: Parsing is important as any progrmming language is a CFL?

q3.description: Why do we care? Because we want to parse efficiently. This means, we want to quickly determine if a given string can be generated from a given grammar. Determinism seems to be a fundamental requirement if we hope to do this.
q3.question: Since programming languages are Context Free Languages. Programming languages must be?

q10.description:
$\textbf{LL(k) Grammars}$
LL means “left-to-right” and “left-most derivation” is constructed. $k$ means that we can look ahead at most $k−1$ characters. Every s-grammar is LL, but so are more grammars.
q10.question: Consider this grammar $S \rightarrow aSb \mid ab$. Is it an S-Grammar?
q10.answer: No, because the variable $S$ has two productions start with the same letter $a$
choices: No, because the variable $S$ has two productions start with the same letter $a$
Yes, the variable $S$ has tow productions start with unique letters

$\textbf{LL(k) Grammars}$
LL means “left-to-right” and “left-most derivation” is constructed. $k$ means that we can look ahead at most $k−1$ characters. Every s-grammar is LL, but so are more grammars.
q11.question: Consider this grammar $S \rightarrow aSb \mid ab$. IF we see a string starts with $ab$, which production we should use to produce that string

q12.description:
$\textbf{LL(k) Grammars}$
LL means “left-to-right” and “left-most derivation” is constructed. $k$ means that we can look ahead at most $k−1$ characters. Every s-grammar is LL, but so are more grammars.
q12.question: Consider this grammar $S \rightarrow aSb \mid ab$. IF we see a string starts with $aa$, which production we should use to produce that string

q15.description:
Consider this grammar: $S ightarrow aSbS \mid \lambda$
This grammar is $LL(k)$. Think about one thing, can we know uniquely which production we should use every time by reading only $k$ letters every time or not.
q15.question: Suppose we need to derive the string $abab$, which production we will use to get the letter $a$
q15.answer: To read $a$ we must use $S\rightarrow aSbS$
choices: To read $a$ we must use $S\rightarrow aSbS$

q16.description:
Consider this grammar: $S ightarrow aSbS \mid \lambda$
This grammar is $LL(k)$. Think about one thing, can we know uniquely which production we should use every time by reading only $k$ letters every time or not.
q16.question: Suppose we need to derive the string $abab$, which production we will use to get the second letter ($b$)
choices: To read $b$ we must use $S\rightarrow aSbS$

q18.question: When we say that a language is DCFL?
answer: if the languages can be accepted by DPDA
if the language has an S-Grammar
if the language has an $LL(k)$ grammar
choices: if the languages can be accepted by DPDA
if the language has an S-Grammar
if the language has an $LL(k)$ grammar
